msItem.title: The Debate between the Body and the Soul
The Life and Passion of St. Blaise
The Life and Passion of St. Cecilia
Four lines of Middle English Verse
Allas deceyte, þat in truste ys nowe
Be þou nou&yogh;t tobolde to blame
Better ys to suffre and fortune abide
He þe wise and wel i tau&yogh;t

handNote.p: The first part of the manuscript, ff. 1r-200r written in the last quarter of the thirteenth century.
The second part of the manuscript, ff. 200v-203v written in the last quarter of the thirteenth century.
The third part of the manuscript, ff. 204r-228r written in the early thirteenth century.
The fourth part of the manuscript, ff. 204r-228r written in a compact textura hand of the early thirteenth century.

The fifth part of the manuscript, ff. 228v-237v written in the late fourteenth century in a script of the same type and date (Anglicana) as that of Cambridge, Magdalene College, Pepys, MS 2498 and London, British Library, Laud Misc. MS 622.
In the sixth part of the manuscript, the top of f. 238 is in a hand of the fifteenth century.
In the sixth part of the manuscript, the verses on the rest of f. 238 are also in a hand of the fifteenth century.

origin.p: ff. 1-198r are written in a W Oxon dialect from around the last quarter of the thirteenth century.
ff. 204r-219v are written in a W Norfolk dialect from around c. 1300.
ff. 219v-228r are written in a W Norfolk dialect with a substratum from SE Surrey, SW Kent, or N Suffolk, from around c. 1300.
ff. 228v-237v were written around the late fourteenth century.
The verses on f. 238 were written in the fifteenth century.

provenance.p: The manuscript was owned by Henry Perveys around 1450-1475.
The manuscript was owned by William Laud in 1633.

history.acquisition: The manuscript was donated to the Bodleian Library by William Laud in 1635.

bibl.ref: All items belong to the LAEME literary category.

note.p: The Bodleian Library stamp and declaration of ownership by Archbishop Laud are currently recorded in the <facsimile> section.

þat power he &yogh;af p P eter þo&punctelev; and alle ís oþere fere,

And alle þe p p&combtildevert; pre latu&slong; of holíe churche : þat after him &slong;ethþe come; The word "holie" in this line represents the scribe's frequent tendency to place the acute-like i-dot over the following glyph. I have not attempted to represent this in the transcriptions. It seems to me that it is best associated with the facsimile layer.
þ Þ arefo&rrot;e ech man heom &slong;cholde a bowíe : þat guode &yogh;eme þarof nome.

p P eter p P eter o&rrot;e louerd &slong;eíde,&punctelev; to IJ erusalem í mot wende There are two folds running down the middle of the parchment from the top of the text down to poetic) line 56 on the left and poetic line 79 on the right. In most cases, there is no uncertainty about the reading but the "s" in "seide" in this line is the first where it needs to be noted. I have not indicated letters affected by these folds unless they are considerably obscured. This note should probably be moved (to right before the next <pb/> element?).
And soffrí muche fo&rrot; mankuínde&punctelev; and þane deth aten ende

s S
Seínt Peter him ladde in conseílle,&punctelev; and seíde louerd þín ore
h H ít ne falleth nou&yogh;t þe swuch þíng to done&punctelev; man to bugge &slong;o &slong;o&rrot;e.

g G o bí h&ydot;nde me o&rrot;e louerd &slong;eíde&punctelev; þou spext a&slong;e mí fo The fold in the parchment hides the "i" in "seide", but the acute-like dot is visible over the "d", confirming the reading.

þ þ ou no&slong;t nou&yogh;t &yogh;wat to gode bifallez&punctelev; ne onder&slong;tonde&slong;t no þe mo This line and the following three lines have a corrupt tile in the digital image. Readings should be checked against the TIFF file.

h H o &slong;o co
cometh after me&punctelev; hím &slong;eelf he mot fo&rrot;&slong;ake The tip of a large triangular hole in the manuscript begins after the first two letters in "cometh". The scribe appears to have begun the word and then thought better of it, starting the word anew on the other side of the hole without erasing the inital "co" he had already written.
h H ís O o wene rode bere and s&ydot;wí me&punctelev; and he wolle to me take

And apeiri ís &slong;elíe &slong;oule&punctelev; me þ&ydot;nchez he bí &yogh;ít wel lu&ydot;te
f F o&rrot; god wole comen atþe la&slong;te&punctelev; and &yogh;íuen euer ech man
After þath he hat here ídon&punctelev; a&slong;e euene a&slong;e he can

After síx dawes þere afterward&punctelev; o&rrot;e louerd ope ane heí&yogh;e hulle gan gon The main body of the ornamental capital drops into line 71, but the left downward strok of the "A" actually descends to the left of the text down to line 80.

þ Þ ere comen tweí &pflour; pro phete&slong;&punctelev; Mo&ydot;&slong;es and h H el&ydot;e

And &slong;peken wíth o&rrot;e louerd I̅u Jesu
c Cri &slong;t&punctelev; þe maydene&slong; &slong;one Maríe I have used the combining mark ̅ for the abbreviation of Jesu, since the stroke does not cross the "h"; it is more like a macron between the "h" and the following vowel. The abbreviation of "Crist" looks like "c" with a minim directly above it. I have used  &openparen;COMBINING LATIN SMALL LETTER DOTLESS I&closeparen; for this mark, but note that this is a PRIVATE USE AREA code point.

þ Þ o &slong;eínt p P eter hadde í&slong;eíd þís word&punctelev; ne mí&yogh;te heom no man íseo Horstmann (p. 32) claims that "Peter fehlt in Ms", but it is clearly there.

þ Þ í&slong; í&slong; mí leoue &slong;one þat í&slong; me leof&punctelev; In hím ís al mí lík&ydot;nge

Note that French stressed final "e" is represented with an acute accent in the critical transcription.
Are ch beo to heuene i went þat &yogh;e ne &slong;eon nou&yogh;t me
A&slong;e þeos de&slong;ciple&slong; to gadere weren heo maden contek and mone Lines 89-90 appear to omit the acute-like dot over i in a systematic manner.

l.note: Approximately 22 lines are missing from the beginning of the page. At this point, a small piece of parchment still bound contains an unidentifiable fragment of an ornamental capital in blue ink, touched with red. Beneath it, presumably the following line is a capital "A", touched with red. Were these remnants to be lineated, they would presumably be lines 103-104, and this is indicated in their @xml:id, albeit with a suffix "a" so that the current lineation can be preserved. If Horstmann transcribed these fragments, they were lost in our OCR.
Another 27 or so lines have been lost due to the tearing of the page. Another fragment remains, probably starting with part of a capital "A" at line 131a.

l.unclear: ut þa oþur bit at þ
l.note: Lines 132a-135a are incomplete, as the parchment is torn on the right before the caesura. Line 132a is torn at more or less the point where the ascenders of letters begin. The presence of distinct thorn descenders make it possible to read the text with some confidence, the least distinct letters being the "b" in "bit", which might be an "s", and the "t" in "at".

div1.l:
þ Þ e oþur wolle ari&slong;e and late lette
Horstmann's emendation of "late" to "lette" may just be an accurate reading of a ligatured or crowded "ett".
Al&slong;o ít fareth of ouwer neode
And &slong;tudefa&slong;tlíche wíth gode

l.note: The folio is torn, with only fragments of lines 177a-180a remaining. There is evidence of about ten letters (including two spaces) in line 177a, but they are all but unreadable.

þo seide ore louerd : þi broþer schal : arise 3et and liue.
Heo seide : ich wot he schal a domes dai : a rise up, ich ileue þe.
Ich am, quad ore louerd, opriste and lijf; : ho so wole bi leue on me,
þei he were ded, 3eot he schal libbe; : and ech man, þat aliue is
And bi leuez on me, he ne schal nou3t deie : with outen ende i wis.
Mi3t þou, Martha, þis i leue? : 3e, louerd! quath heo,
Ich wot þat þou art godes sone, : þat in þis worlde wolt beo.
þo orn Martha to hire soster hom : and bad hire þat heo wende
Stille liche and with ore louerd speke, : for aftur hire he sende-
Marie a ros up stilleliche, : wel glad heo gan forth gon;
þe giwes, þat hyre conforti scholden, : heo þou3ten and seiden a non:
Fram us heo geth þus stilleliche, : we wuten wel 3wat it is;
For heo wole gon to hire broþur and wepe more : and sle hire self iwis;
Siwe we hire, 3if we mouwe : ani confort hire do !
Marie cam to ore louerd sone, : and þe giwes with hire al so,
And þe giwes weopen alle forth with hire; : louerd, heo seide, þin ore !
Marie ful to ore louerdes fet : wepinde swiþe sore:
Mi broþer nadde nou3t i beo ded, : 3if þou haddest ibeon him nei3.
And ore louerd him self wepte sore, : þo he þis deol isei3.
þe giwes seiden, þo heo iseien wepe, : nov we mowe iseo,
Hou muche he louede him, : 3wane he wole for him so sori be.
Ore louerd het heom þat heo þat lid : of þe þrouwe a wei bere.
Louerd! quath Martha, he stinkez foule, : four dawes he hath i beo þere,
Ne habbe ich iseid, quath ore louerd, : þat 3e mowe iseo
Godes mi3te, 3if 3e wollez : of gode bi leue beo?
þo þat lid was awei inome, : ore louerd bi heold up softe;
Fader! he seide, ich þonki þe : þat þou hast iherd me ofte;
I heor me nouþe and schev þi grace, : fader! ich bidde þe,
þat þis folk aboute i leue it wel : þat þou sendest hidere to me!
þo bi gan ore louerd loude to grede, : cum out, Lazar, a non!
He a ros up fram deþe to liue, : and hol gan forth gon,
With listene i bounde ase he was, : and In a cloth i wounde.
Mani giv turnede þare to god : for þe miracles þat heo founde.
Ore louerd het heom don a wei ech del : and late him gon on bounde.
þe apostles deliuereden him anon, : is limes were hole and sounde.
A non so ore louerd het Lazar come out, : as þe bok us doth telle,
þe bodi wende out of þrouwe a non, : and þe soule cam out of helle;
For seint Austin seith þat Lazar tolde : heom, þat weren him nei3,
Muche of þe priuete of helle, : þat he þare Inne i sei3.
þis word was sone wide ibrou3t : to þe heie maistres of þe lawe,
Hou ore louerd hadde Lazar a rerd; þat folk gan to him drawe.
Gret conseil heo maden a non : and seiden heom bi tuene:
3if we ani 3wyle þus lateth him gon, : he wole us don gret teone,
þis folk wole al to him tuyrne, : þe romains us wollez ouer come,
And þoru3 heom ore men and al heore lond : sone us worth bi nome.
Cayfas þat was hore bischop, : ase god wolde, he gan telle:
Betere is þat on deie for men, : þane al fok go into helle.
Of him sulf ne seide he nou3t þat, : for he wende wel to lie,
Ake ore louerd wolde þat he seide soth : In manere of prophecie.
Fram þulke time after ward : heo a waiteden wel bliue
To nimen ore louerd and Lazar : and bringe heom beine of liue.
Ore louerd wende with is desciples : bi side desert a luyte
Into þe cite of Effrem, : þare he bi lefde 3uyte.
þe feste of ester was ful nei3, þare fore eche daye ene
To þe temple þe giwes wenden : to make heom þare a3en clene,
And þou3ten also þat ore louerd wolde : sum time þudere come,
A3en þe heie feste, þat heo mi3ten : a waiti þat he were inome.
Heo leten crie oueral a boute, : 3if ani man mi3te onder 3ite
Ani þing of him in anie stude, : Men scholden heom do to wite.
A palmesonendayes eue ore louerd wende : to Martha and to Marie,
þare ase he Lazare arerde, : bi side Bethanie.
Symound leprous was a man : þat Musel hadde ibeo longe,
Ake ore louerd him hadde iheld bi fore : of is vueles þat weren stronge.
Jn is hous ore louerd lefde ate mete, : and is desciples also,
And Lazar þat he to liue brou3te, : and is sostrene two.-
Martha heom seruede atþe mete; : Marie nam anon
Boxes of guode smeorijnge, : to ore louerd heo gan go,
His heued he smeorede and is fet; : al þat hous was suote;
þat oygnement was of spikenard :þat mani may do bote.
Jvdas bar ore louerd panes, : strong þeof heo was inov3,
þar of he stal ri3t to grounde, : to falshede euere he drou3;
For manie Men 3eouen ore louerd guod, : þat weren of guod þou3t,
To sosteyni þare is desciples; : oþur panes ne hadde he nou3t.
Of eche þinge atþe laste : Jvdas wolde stele;
A schewe he was al is lijf; : 3wat helpeth lengore (to hele)?
þo ore louerd was i smeored with þat oygnement : þat Marie hadde ibore:
3wat, seide Judas, schal þis i do : swuch guod þing beon for lore?
For þre houndret panes man mi3te it sulle : and to pouere men it 3iue,
þanne nere it nou3t þus for lore, : 3if it holpe to hore bi liue.
Al þat he seide, for he wolde : þat þe boxes hadden ibeo sold,
And habbe i spendet þe panes in sume þinge, : and to him euere at holde.-
þe teoþinge was þar of þritti panes, : sore him of þou3te þere fore
þat so manie panes of is þeofþe : fram him scholden ben ibore.
For wrathþe þarof, to coueri sethþe : þulke panes, 3if he mi3te,
He solde ore louerd for þritti panes : to þe giwes with oute ri3te.
þo he for þat oygnement : with Marie chide bi gan :
3wat beo 3e nouþe, ore louerd seide, : wroþe with þis womman?
In me nouþe and al so bi fore : guod weork heo hath i do;
Pouere Men 3e schulle euere among ou habbe, : and me 3e ne schulle nou3t so.
Soffrieth þat heo wite sum, : for to ich ibured beo,
And lateth hire þanne to me come, for heo me schal sone iseo.
Ore louerd het tweine of his Apostles : a palmesonenday at non,
þat heo scholden a luy t e þare bi side : In to a Castel gon;
An Asse colt i teid to is moder, he seide, : þare 3e schulle iseo,
Ope 3wam no man ne hath 3eot iride; : onteiez it and bringez it me !
Seggez þat Ich habbe þare with to done, : 3if ani Man Axez ou3t!
His desciples wenden and founden þat colt, : þo heo it hadde isou3t.
Ase heo it onteiden, þe Maister heom axede, : 3wat heo wolden þare with so sone.
And heo seiden þat heore Maister : þare with hadde to done.
He grauntede heom þo al sauueliche : to lede it forth wel faste.
In heore hond heo ladden it forth, : and cloþus þare upe heo caste,
An sethþe on ouewarde heo setten ore louerd ; : mildeliche he it bistrod;
Toward is deþe, ase he wel wuste, : to is fo men he rod,
þat hadden him suyþe wide isou3t : and nemi3ten him finde nou3t.
He wende forth a mong heomalle, : þat is dethz nere destourbet nou3t-
With 3wat pruyte cam he a mong is fon, : ase bi fel a king to do !
Barefot op on þe Asse he rod, : ihaltred heo was also.
A doun of þe hul of oliuete : þe 3onge Men isei3en him ride;
Huy þou3ten hov he brou3te Lazare to liue, : þarof Men speken wide,
And þare fore wilneden muche him for to seo, : þei þe mai¬stres wroþe were.
For Joye heo strepten of heore cloþes, : and onder þe Asse fet heom casten þere.
Children þat guode cloþes nadden, : þe bowes of Oliue heo nome
And casten onder þe Asse fet, : ase heo a3ein him come;
Heil beo þou, Dauies sone, : ore king, heil þou beo !
I blessed beo þou þat comest In godes name, : þat we þe mouwen i seo!
So muche eorthþelich manschipe : ore louerd on eorþe nadde,
Neuere þat we findez i write, : ase he þat dai hadde.
þe Maistres weren wroþe with þe 3onge men : þat him honoureden so,
And þretneden heom for heo scholden : swuch manschipe heore fo do-
Ne beoth nou3t wroþe with heom! ore louerd seide, : for, 3if þat huy nolde
Habbe iwelcomed me wit honour, : for soþe þe stones wolde.
Eft sone ichulle on eorþe come : atþe daie of dome,
Wel grislich bi tokninge men schullen i seo : þare a3ein ilome
In sonne, and Mone, and steorrene also, : and eorþe greoue Men schulle ise,
Hongur, fi3tinge, and tricherie : among Men muche schal beo,
And lasse loue þane euere was; : and 3wane 3e iseoth al þis,
Witez wel þat domes day : ne cometh nou3t anon iwis.
Ore louerd, þo he cam to Jerusalem, : he stod and bi heold aboute;
He bi heold þe cite þat was so fair, : þe boldes þat weren so proute.
He bi þou3te him, and bigan to siche, : and weop sore with alle,
And seide : Jerusalem, 3if þou wustest : 3wat þe schal bi falle,
þov woldest also weope sore ! : for þou art nouþe ibrou3t
In alle Joye and in gret pouwer, ake þe ende nost þou nou3t;
For þine fon þe schullen bi legge : and þe wel narewe driue,
And to grounde bringe atþe laste, : and þine children bringe of liue;
þare ne schal aston op oþur bi leue, : þat ne worth a doun iþrowe;
For þou nelt nou3t þine tyme : of þine sauuinge iknowe.
Bi Tytus and Vaspasian : ore louerd seide al þis,
þat Jerusalem to grounde brou3te : and destruyden sethþe i wis.
Ore louerd was þo ful sore aflngred; : to þe temple he gan gon,
A figer he fond faire ileued, : ake fruyt ne bar heo non.
Nou ne wexe þare no þing : neuerefft, figer , of þe,
For þov noldest nouþe In mine neode : no fruyt bere to helpe me!
þe figer felde a non is lef, : þo he hadde þis ibede,
And fur weolewede ase a stok, : þare ne bi lefde nou3t a grene stude,
His desciples, þo heo þis i seie, gret wonder hadden with alle.
3if 3e weren of studefaste bi leue, ore louerd seide, : so it scholde ou falle,
Treon ne scholden nou3t one eov abouwie, : ac, 3if þat 3e hote wolden
Hulles to fallen In þe se, : a non ri3tes heo scholden.
To þe temple ore louerd wende anon, : and fond he þer Inne
Chap Men stondinde and sullen orf, : hore lijflode forto winne,
Schep and reþren, and coluerene eke, : and Muneteres also,
þat oncouþe Men mi3ten moneie finde : heore offringe forto do.
Ore louerd heom drof wel stuyrneliche : out of þe temple a non,
Chapmen, sullares, and buggares, : þare Inne he ne lefde nou3t on.
þe Muteres Moneye he schedde al, : and þe bordes ouer turnde;
No man nemoste nou3t bere þare Inne, : þat he anon heom wernde.
Min hous is þe stude of beden, : it is iwrite, ore louerd seide,
And nou3t to bugge þar Jnne and sulle, : ne don no þeues dede.
3wane he was so wroth for Marchaundise : þat he In þe temple i sai3,
Hov wroth wole he beo with cristine Men : þat gangliez In churche al dai !
þe giwes weren with him wel wroþe : þat he tok on so,
And seiden : 3wat signe hastou for þe, : þat þou þus mi3t do?
Bringez þe temple, ore louerd seide, : 3if 3e wollez, to grounde,
And Jch as wolle þane þridde day : arere op In one stounde.
Bi þe temple of is owene bodi : þat word he hath iseid,
þat he wolde a rere np þane þridde dai : after þat he was ded.
þe giwes onder stoden bi þe grete temple : þat heo Inne were.
Hov mi3te it beo, heo seiden, þat þis Man : fals and luþer nere!
For a buyldinge heo was sixe and fourti 3er : and 3eot more In þe 3ere;
3wam þenchez him sulue make : þat so sone as wolde a rere!
Some seiden þat he was gylour strong, : some þat he was guod.
þo gan ore louerd prechi of clergie : and hardeliche forth stod:
Mi clergie ne cometh nou3t of me, ore louerd seide, : ac of him þat me hidere sende.
Hou can he of clergie? þis oþur seiden, : to schole neuere he ne wende.
3wi a waytie me for to quelle? ore louerd sede, : 3wat habbe ich ou misdo?
Is þe deuel on þe, (þe) giwes seiden, : ho awaitiez þe so?
3e beoth wroþe for ich helde men : In þe sabat, ore louerd seide;
Ne seith nou3t ouwer lawe of Moyses, : 3wane 3e þaro wollez rede,
þat 3e schullen beo J circumcized : þene ei3tiþe dai þat 3e i bore beth,
þei it falle on a sabat, : ase 3e aldai i seoth?
And þat ouwere soule for to hele; : 3wi ne mot ich also
þe soule bote and þe bodies : In þe sabat do?
Is it þes, manie seiden, : þat þe Maistres a waytiez forto quelle?
And þerof ne seggez nouþe neuere a word, : of al þat he a3en hem tellez.
þe Maistres heom bi þou3ten narewe, : hou heo mi3ten best ontake,
þat ore louerd were priueliche inome, : þat folk þar of ne speke.
With oute conseille of some of his : heo ne dorsten bi ginne it nou3t,
Ne In non halidai, laste þat folk : In destourbaunce were ibrou3t.
Euereche daie fram palmesonen Eue : for to schere þores dai
Ore louerd wende a ni3t to Betanie : and with Symon leprous lay.
To þe temple he wende a 3en, : anon so it was dai li3t,
A3en þe heie feste to schewi him, : and to is Inne he eode a ni3t.
þe deuel þat hadde to ore louerd onde, : he wende into Judas;
His In was euere a redi þere, : for euere a schrewe he was ;
He eggede him þat he scholde sone : þe giwes ore louerd take.
þene wodnesdai þe giwes comen : and mid him þarof spake.
Jvdas i sai heore grete wille :3if heom þare of mi3te spede,
And þou3te þat he nolde him nou3t bitake, : bote heo him 3eouen is mede.
He þou3te on þe þritti panes of teoþinge : þat to him wolde habbe iwend.
